ROW.COLUMN:
Reason for Admission: The patient was admitted to Mercy General Hospital on April 20, 2024, following an episode of self-harm involving multiple lacerations to the left forearm. The patient presented with moderate bleeding and reported a history of chronic depression and anxiety. The patient has suicide intention. Self-Injurious Behavior Poisoning by aspirin, intentional self-harm Hospital Course: During the hospital stay, the patient was evaluated and treated by the medical and psychiatric teams. Key interventions included:
Medical Management:
Wound care provided for lacerations, including cleaning, suturing, and dressing. Administration of antibiotics to prevent infection. Regular monitoring of vital signs, all of which remained stable throughout the stay. Psychiatric Evaluation:
Comprehensive psychiatric evaluation conducted, confirming diagnoses of Major Depressive Disorder and Anxiety Disorder. Initiation of antidepressant therapy with Sertraline 50 mg daily. Introduction of PRN (as needed) Lorazepam 0.5 mg for acute anxiety episodes. Therapeutic Interventions:
Individual therapy sessions focused on cognitive-behavioral strategies and identifying triggers for self-harm. Family therapy sessions were conducted to educate and involve family members in the patient’s treatment plan. Social Work and Case Management:
Assessment for social support and development of a safety plan. Referrals provided for outpatient follow-up with community mental health services and support groups. Discharge Plan: The patient is being discharged in stable condition with the following plan:
Medications:
Sertraline 50 mg, take one tablet daily. Lorazepam 0.5 mg, take one tablet as needed for anxiety (not to exceed 3 tablets per day). Follow-up Appointments:
Psychiatric follow-up with Dr. Emily Carter on May 10, 2024. Primary care follow-up with Dr. Robert Lee on May 15, 2024. Therapeutic Services:
Continue with individual therapy sessions at Horizon Behavioral Health. Attend group therapy sessions at the local community center every Wednesday at 6 PM. Safety Plan:
Removal of sharp objects and medications from accessible areas in the home. Emergency contacts include the Crisis Hotline (1-800-273-8255) and local emergency services (911). Educational Materials:
Provided educational materials on coping strategies for self-harm, signs of relapse, and available support resources. Emergency Instructions:
In case of a crisis or emergency, the patient is instructed to go to the nearest emergency room or contact the crisis hotline at 1-800-273-8255. Summary: The patient has shown improvement during the hospital stay and is discharged with a comprehensive plan for ongoing care and support. It is essential that the patient adheres to the follow-up appointments and therapeutic interventions to ensure continued progress and stability.

Continue with individual therapy sessions at Horizon Behavioral Health. Attend group therapy sessions at the local community center every Wednesday at 6 PM. Safety Plan:
Removal of sharp objects and medications from accessible areas in the home. Emergency contacts include the Crisis Hotline (1-800-273-8255) and local emergency services (911). Educational Materials:
Provided educational materials on coping strategies for self-harm, signs of relapse, and available support resources. Emergency Instructions:
In case of a crisis or emergency, the patient is instructed to go to the nearest emergency room or contact the crisis hotline at 1-800-273-8255. Summary: The patient has shown improvement during the hospital stay and is discharged with a comprehensive plan for ongoing care and support. It is essential that the patient adheres to the follow-up appointments and therapeutic interventions to ensure continued progress and stability.

Reason for Admission: The patient was admitted to Mercy General Hospital on April 20, 2024, following an episode of self-harm involving multiple lacerations to the left forearm. The patient presented with moderate bleeding and reported a history of chronic depression and anxiety. The patient has suicide intention. Self-Injurious Behavior Poisoning by aspirin, intentional self-harm Hospital Course: During the hospital stay, the patient was evaluated and treated by the medical and psychiatric teams. Key interventions included:
Medical Management:
Wound care provided for lacerations, including cleaning, suturing, and dressing. Administration of antibiotics to prevent infection. Regular monitoring of vital signs, all of which remained stable throughout the stay. Psychiatric Evaluation:
Comprehensive psychiatric evaluation conducted, confirming diagnoses of Major Depressive Disorder and Anxiety Disorder. Initiation of antidepressant therapy with Sertraline 50 mg daily. Introduction of PRN (as needed) Lorazepam 0.5 mg for acute anxiety episodes. Therapeutic Interventions:
Individual therapy sessions focused on cognitive-behavioral strategies and identifying triggers for self-harm. Family therapy sessions were conducted to educate and involve family members in the patient’s treatment plan. Social Work and Case Management:
Assessment for social support and development of a safety plan. Referrals provided for outpatient follow-up with community mental health services and support groups. Discharge Plan: The patient is being discharged in stable condition with the following plan:
Medications:
Sertraline 50 mg, take one tablet daily. Lorazepam 0.5 mg, take one tablet as needed for anxiety (not to exceed 3 tablets per day). Follow-up Appointments:
Psychiatric follow-up with Dr. Emily Carter on May 10, 2024. Primary care follow-up with Dr. Robert Lee on May 15, 2024. Therapeutic Services:
Continue with individual therapy sessions at Horizon Behavioral Health. Attend group therapy sessions at the local community center every Wednesday at 6 PM. Safety Plan:
Removal of sharp objects and medications from accessible areas in the home. Emergency contacts include the Crisis Hotline (1-800-273-8255) and local emergency services (911). Educational Materials:
Provided educational materials on coping strategies for self-harm, signs of relapse, and available support resources. Emergency Instructions:
In case of a crisis or emergency, the patient is instructed to go to the nearest emergency room or contact the crisis hotline at 1-800-273-8255. Summary: The patient has shown improvement during the hospital stay and is discharged with a comprehensive plan for ongoing care and support. It is essential that the patient adheres to the follow-up appointments and therapeutic interventions to ensure continued progress and stability.
